snippet.title: Osprey mishap: US Marines aircraft located at Shoalwater Bay off Rockhampton
snippet.content:
The submerged remains of a US military aircraft that crashed off Queensland's coast, leaving three marines presumed dead, has been found, Defence Minister Marise Payne has confirmed. Ms Payne said the aircraft - an MV-22 Osprey - was found by HMAS Melville, which arrived in Shoalwater Bay overnight. The during a training exercise on Saturday afternoon, 23 of the 26 crew members on board were rescued.
, and moved to a recovery and salvage phase expected to take several months. Two marines - Lt. Benjamin Robert Cross and Corporal Nathan Ordway - have been identified by family. Lt. Cross' brother Ryan Cross today said his younger sibling had the "highest moral character" and was "devoted" to the Marine Corps. Corporal Ordway's family and friends took to social media to call for prayers. "Please pray for his life, his safety, and comfort for the family," family friend Heidi Peltzer wrote on Facebook. One more of the 26 personnel who were onboard remains missing, presumed dead, but is yet to be identified. Another is recovering in a Brisbane hospital with a leg injury. A number of Australian Defence Force (ADF) assets were involved in supporting the US-led recovery operation, including HMAS Melville and a Navy clearance diving team.
